newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenian shares tumble ahead of new stock tax.
newsitem.headline: Slovenian shares tumble ahead of new stock tax.

text.p: Slovenian shares fell 1.47 percent on Monday as investors in shares of newly privatised firms rushed to cash in profits ahead of a new 25-percent tax on profits from securities.
The same tax that already applies to companies will be extended to individuals from January 1, 1997.
The 10-share SBI index fell 17.36 points to 1,167.3.
"Many small shareholders of newly privatised companies who bought shares with privatisation vouchers decided to sell before the end of the year in order to avoid the new tax," one broker said.
"If individuals continue to sell in large amounts, prices could fall further this week," she added.
But she said shares could rebound just before the end of the year because of book balancing.
Turnover jumped to 250.7 million tolars from 192.8 million. Overall nine shares fell, four rose and one remained unchanged, while 11 were untraded.
Drug maker Lek's "A" issue was the most actively traded, falling 0.76 percent to 19,690 tolars on volume of 7,946 shares.
Financial consultancy Finmedia was the day's leading decliner, falling 4.82 percent or 790 tolars to 15,600 tolars on volume of 20 shares.
Brokerage Dadas was the biggest gainer, firming 11 percent to 8,880 tolars on volume of 83 shares.
